entry.title: Ruby Multidimensional Arrays
entry.content:
Today, when I use Two-dimensional array with ruby.

Like:

``` ruby

arr=[]
arr2=[]
3.times  { arr2 << "_" } 
3.time   {arr << arr2}

```

And when I change the arr[1][1] to "-"

It will show:

```

 _ - _
 _ - _
 _ - _

```

But what I want is :

```

_ _ _
_ - _
_ _ _

```

I did not know why this happened. So I search it by search engineer.

And I found a differen thing in ruby.

If you want to output right image. Like above.

You need init your array like this:

ruby arr=[[" _"," _"," _"],[" _"," _"," _"],[" _"," _"," _"]]

The Reason

When you use te first way to create a two-dimensinol array.

The sub array point to the same object arr2.

``` ruby Array.new(3, Array.new(3,0)).each{|i|p i.object_id} -616182288 -616182288 -616182288

[[0, 0, 0], [0, 0, 0], [0, 0, 0]].each{|i|p i.object_id} -616198918 -616198928 -616198938

```

entry.title: Ruby's Multiline
entry.content:
How to show mutilines in Ruby’s code

In summary, there are 2 ways:

1 use %q{}

For example:

x = %q{ line1
line2
line3}

or use %q!! %q() and so on

2 use Here Document

And you can use here document

For example:

x = <<here_document
line1
line2
here_document

Use << start with some strings, like the abrove, use <<here_document

And ended with the strings.
